It refers to the forced relocation of Native American tribes, particularly the Cherokee, Creek, Seminole, Chickasaw, and Choctaw nations, from their ancestral homelands in the southeastern United States to designated "Indian Territory" west of the Mississippi River during the 1830s. This relocation was carried out under the Indian Removal Act of 1830, signed into law by President Andrew Jackson.

Thousands of Native Americans died during these forced marches due to exposure, disease, starvation, and exhaustion. The event is supported by extensive historical records, including government documents, personal accounts, letters, and official reports. To suggest it was a "fabrication" is not only historically inaccurate but also deeply disrespectful to the memory of those who suffered and died.
